147929453.review:
[u]Recommendation[/u]: An engaging exploration game about the robots terraforming Mars, told satisfyingly in four chapters and ending with an almost entirely unrelated appendix fifth chapter.

[u]Critique[/u]: The game is immersive, with lots of humor and voice acting telling a story about robots given a bleak task to save humanity. It is so immersive that you have to explore/intuit the controls. I was able to figure out how to do nearly everything because it has controls in common with most other games. But I was more than halfway through the game before I figured out how to "run." So, in case anyone else is as slow as I was, here are the controls:
WA - forward/backward, AD - strafe left/right, Mouse - aim, Left mouse button - grab/release, Right mouse button - sonic punch, Spacebar - jump (double jumping possible), Shift - hold to run. There are places in the game where navigating the level is much easier if you know how to run and jump; because I hadn't figure it out by that point in the game, it became a very complicated game of precision parkour. Learn from my mistake!

I really, really enjoyed this. I found the mechanism of interacting with droids to get pieces of the story told through dialogue really engaging and fun. So the final chapter had me puzzled, as it's a complete departure from everything in the rest of the game: different character, different location, different controls, different lighting, different story (the only possible context you might have is given by an overheard conversation you can easily miss in chapter 1). The controls in this last part were particularly frustrating, as there is no ability to strafe: it's all tank steering, in which you rotate the body and move forward. I got stuck several times when I overshot a jump and then had to turn in complete darkness, unsure which direction my character was facing. It's a disappointing and confusing denouement to the game to me, as the first four chapters told such an engaging narrative.

[u]Review[/u]: In the future when travel to Mars is feasible, the Earth's climate has gone haywire, leading to a severe Ice Age that has left no part of the Earth with a growing zone. Life as we know it is ending on Earth, so the humans initiate two parallel efforts to save everything: [spoiler]drilling to the center of the Earth, and drilling to the center of Mars. Both of these schemes involve doing something with the core of the planet to produce enough heat to make the planet livable. Mars has been a destination for space tourists for some time, and though there are no long-term human colonies on Mars because the radiation from space kills Terrestrial life fairly quickly, they have found bacteria, suggesting that more complex life could be sustained on Mars under the right conditions. So an enormous operation is started on Mars, with huge factories in orbit creating and maintaining a work force of sentient robots whose job it is to terraform the planet. The game begins as the robots on Mars have already built a space elevator and various science and engineering bases on the surface. They have a huge drill assembly that is burrowing down into the planet, trying to reach the core that they hope to ignite (the details of "how?" and "why?" are a little light here - it may be that the assumption is that the core is a ferrous solid, and they want to somehow raise the temperature to turn it molten so that the convection of the iron will create stronger magnetic fields to shield the planet from cosmic radiation, but none of that is explained).  But the deeper they've drilled into the planet, the more marsquakes they've experienced, to the point that their installations are taking damage and the robots are skeptical that their operations will be able to continue for much longer. You play a DOG unit, a fusion-powered robot floating on four fusion thrusters with manipulators that enable you to lift, toss, and destroy items using powerful force fields. The robots have sent drones down into the drill shaft, and they haven't returned or reported in, so you're being sent to find them and retrieve whatever data they recorded. On the way, you help out a number of android robots who are slower, clumsier, and less capable than you are: finding a box in a sandstorm and loading it onto the space elevator, refueling a generator for the greenhouse experiments, etc. Descending into the mine to find the drones, you are accompanied by a chatty robot, Android 42, whose job it is to copy the data from the drones while your job is to find and clear a path to them. On the way you find that, deep inside Mars, there are ancient tunnels that have been excavated over centuries by directed flows of running water, and then you find statues with hands and faces, suggesting that humanoid life existed on Mars at some point. But just as you gather the last drone's data, the most severe marsquake yet hits, and the DOG and android 42 run desperately through the tunnels trying to escape. Eventually they are crushed. In the final chapter, you are a cat in the control station built on top of the massive excavator on Earth, racing to not get left behind when the humans activate the drill. As a cat, you can't really interact with your environment in any way, and there is no dialogue. You can run and jump to navigate the extremely dark (all the lights are off) human environment, all while steering like a tank. The game ends as you are caught in a cage just shy of freedom.[/spoiler]

A short 'walking sim' type game with a few puzzles, it's a nice little time killer. There wasn't all that much story in it and the humour was...immature, I suppose?  Although i did appreciate the 'Turtles all the way down' comment. It's just a bit hard to believe that androids would talk this way to each other, they all sounded like frat boys.

Other than that it played well, there were a few 'interaction puzzles' and the achievements forced you to replay a couple of levels to max them out but once you played the levels once it was extremely fast the second time. The ending was unsatisfying in my opinion and a little confusing - I'm unsure what the point of the whole game was if you  end up like that anyway? What did we achieve? And the prologue - as much as I appreciate the furry friend, why? Was it just because the dev wanted to play with the creation and textures or did it mean something? 

Saying that, it still looked nice and ran fine. I think I got this in a Humble Bundle several years ago and only just played it now but for a lost cost, short  walking sim, it's a fair play.

A short sci-fi story with some optional exploration elements in which you are a robot[spoiler]and a cat,[spoiler]then a dog[spoiler]that maybe sees a cat,[spoiler]then you are a cat[spoiler]and then another cat.[/spoiler][/spoiler][/spoiler][/spoiler][/spoiler]

Plays like an homage to classic sci-fi and I'm looking forward to Episode II.

It's a one-person studio creation: sure, animation may be minimal, but focus is elsewhere, on five brief chapters, each with their own location, and dialogue and structure that suggests a thousand story threads converging on this robot's evolving mission.

Overall the pacing was fine and I enjoyed the final straight. I thought of those that first introduced me to sci-fi novels like Heinlein's.

Ran on an i5 with UHD 620 integrated graphics at lowest settings but didn't like having the laptop closed on it, so watch out for that. The chapters are concise enough that you can soon catch up, and the developer is responsive to questions.

[b] I am a Gem Crusader, searching through the piles of underrated & unnoticed games under the ever growing shitpile of games on STEAM, in the hopes of finding a GEM... Hence "Gem Crusader" - A GEM of a game, that simply blows your mind in either gameplay, effort or just both! [/b]

[h1] CAT Interstallar is one of such GEMS [/h1]

So under that pile, I found this game, priced at 39 cents so it's not a risk to my wallet. Because hidden gems are ussually priced that low. A little sparkle, waiting to be found or luring you to it's misery. Well, CAT Interstellar has blown my mind. Not perfectly programmed, but you can clearly see the effort. Not a money grabber at all. 

The voice acting took me on surprise, totally not expected for a game of it's caliber. The story was actually quite compelling, kept me on playing it. This game is merely a demonstration from possibly a bigger story. I guess they changed the title, I could swear that it said "chapter one" or "demo" or something... Meh, probably play too many games, get confused all the time...

Even the achievements showed I finished chapter 3, so maybe I am missing something here. Like it feels the game is unfinished, that this is just a demo.

Streamed this game and even my viewers were curious about the unfolding of it's story. Not just ME saying it :D

Glad the developers decided to raise the price. Therefor hoping, they will continue with the story, like:

[h1] I licked the glassy rim of the Gem Jam, now I want to dive in! [/h1]

So I was a little bit curious about the name CAT, like I was thinking of a cat appearing somewhere. Yet I played a "DOG", robotically but still... But at the end of this demo/chapter, things went a bit weird, it took the seriousness away in an instance. But funny, nonetheless. I just call it an "Easteregg"
And looking back at the achievements, if I just looked a little bit more around and be a little bit more curious, I would have found a little bit more. I just didn't expected that much... My bad... 

If you are interested in a new, fresh & compelling story, taking shape under futuristic and basic circumstances (high tech & underground caves), try this game out! About an hour gameplay, roughly. You will notice some flaws, but they are forgiven as those are no game breakers.

[h1] Is this game a GEM? : YES
Verdict: YES [/h1]

This game has the following
Good points

4. the ending is thought provoking
5. the peek back into the game from the credits level

85187685.review:
A wonderful short story adventure with great atmosphere, visuals and sound. Simple and intriguing. The voice acting was well done. Bravo! I honestly would love to see a much longer, more in-depth version so I can explore more and discover the history of the androids and Earth! If you're looking for something relaxing, fun, interesting and enjoyable, THIS is the game for you. 

Bug Report:
I only found one issue that forced me to restart the second chapter. Above and to the right of the mine entrance, up the hill a bit, there is a gap between the rocks that allows you to fall behind the mine shaft entrance building. And, become permanently stuck in a rock tomb. Since I came to the mine shaft entrance from the direction of the greenhouse and the solar panels, I didn't realize I had discovered a death trap during my explorations until it was far too late. One more large boulder to plug that hole should fix it right up so no one else falls back there.

To the devs:
Finding the memorials for your pets was both heartwarming and saddening. I am sorry for your losses.

74491829.review:
first of all: it's free. you lose nothing by playing this.

that being said, if "time" is what you're worried about losing, understand that this is a very nice game. it's easy, it's chill, there's no frills, there's an interesting twist at the end, and it's a little cute.

but most importantly, it feels like a design exercise by some very competent game designers. there's no Press X To Action thing here. everything the game wants you to do, it teaches you organically. and the androids are cool to hang around too. overall i definitely recommend this game as a neat short story experience by a team that clearly has a bright future ahead of them.

72202100.review:
I'm not recommending this game even though it's free, and here's why: I bought it when it was being sold as Early Access. Then the developers abandoned it and finally made it into what it is now. But that's not the only or main reason.

The story can be played through in about an hour, and does have some interesting (and surprising!) events, but most of it is not interactive. Even though it's called "Cat" interstellar, the main part of the story is about a robot designed after a dog!

When I played it, there was another unconnected proof-of-concept area where the player could control a kitten and make it romp around a room, but ultimately not really DO anything. I would have to replay the game to see if ANYTHING got added between when I played it (and monetarily supported its development) and now, but I honestly cannot muster the desire. 

Ultimately, I suppose this could be a fun diversion for an hour if you have nothing else to do, especially since it's now free, but other than that I would rather play something else.

71462897.review:
Mixed feelings about this one.

Pros: 
* Native Linux version
* Short. Even with the achievement hunting it can be finished in under two hours.
* Looks nice
* Sounds nice
* Contains a rare example of a space elevator in fiction
* Developer makes the project files available as DLC so you can study them if you're new to Unreal Engine 4 development.

Cons: 
* Story seems better-suited to a longer game
* Unsatisfying ending
* Game takes up a LOT of disk space for its length
* Subtitles not enabled by default and does not remember the setting between sessions.
* Forced to walk through the space station to the chapter select every time.

Overall verdict: Tentative recommendation. Play it through and get all the achievements, then uninstall it. Only worth keeping around on your hard drive if you're studying the project files.

Fun little game while it lasted, especially if you have an interest in space (or animals) and hunting down achievements. Took me around 35 minutes to finish the game and then the rest of the time I spent mopping up the achievements I'd missed. There is a chapter select option which really helps with this. I'm guessing whoever made this likes animals. You play a robot dog and also (too briefly) a cat at the end and there's also a little hidden cave that contains graves for some lost pets :(

The graphics are pretty good as is the voice acting for the robots. I did have to enable V-Sync as I was suffering from terrible screen tearing initially but it was all good after this. It's free to play anyways so what's not to like? I think it makes for a great palate cleanser between bigger games.

This game can be finished in one sitting, about total of 1 h of gameplay, but can be picked up pretty cheap on sale. It's a sci-fi story when Earth is dying and people are trying to terraform Mars via android bots to move there. You will play 90% of the game on the surface of Mars. Well the other 10%, which includes an ending which I don't know how it really fits the original story, well, you'll see... that's why it's call CAT Interstellar I think...

51249122.review:
My overall thoughts on the game is more mixed than negative, but I'm leaving a negative review because the cons hit harder than the pros. I'll say that the game looks great and the overall gameplay is fine for a game like this. Some people may have a problem with how short it is for $5 (i don't think $5 is bad, but I'll just say I beat it in an hour with about 15-20 minutes probably just me being lost or not knowing what to do). 

The problems for me really come from the story. The voice acting is really mediocre, which some may be fine with cause it's all coming from androids so robotic acting is passable for them. It's not for me though. It made some of the more serious moments later on less impactful. 

The shortness of the story only became a problem for me right at the end. It started really picking up and had me super hooked on where it's going, but then it just ends. This could work as an episodic series, like this being episode 1 and then maybe we continue as one of the androids or something. However, at the time of this review, it's been almost 2 years since release and nothing more has come of this game. 

There's also some nitpicky problems like the main character being called "Dog" by everyone cause it's a dog unit. There's only so many times I can hear these androids say "dog" before it sounds like an adult or grandparent trying to look cool in front of the kids, especially because of the voice acting. 

Overall, I kinda enjoyed my time, but with the many problems I had, it's really hard to recommend at full price. During a sale, sure go for it.

50738976.review:
Cat Interstellar drew me in by mentioning it was based off of a short story from Robert A Heinlein whose writing I enjoy. The developer was also a delight to deal with on the Steam forums trying to help out whenever they could with issues which is always good to see. I really wanted to like this game and in some ways I did but overall it had too many negatives to recommend it. 

	 The gameplay itself is simple but enjoyable. You play as a Dog class android whose job it is to go down to Mars and investigate missing androids who got lost in some caves as well as optionally help out with other tasks to reveal more backstory. The gameplay is mainly completing tasks like navigating the evnvironment and turning on consoles. The intro to the game brings you to a hub area where you can choose which mission to play. You can play them in order or not. The game is not a long game. I finished the 5 missions in 52 minutes. The story is the real strength as well as a sore spot. I really liked where it was going and the potential of it but I feel it was not explored enough as well as the ending was really abrupt. It leaves many questions that our imaginations aren’t given enough details to really fill in. 

	I played Cat Interstellar on Linux. I had many crashes when the game was trying to launch over the last several months. It worked fine when I first bought it but then started crashing a while later. I tried several different Linux distros with different kernels and Mesa drivers. Luckily the game started launching again recently so I decided to play through it while I could. The game never crashed once it launched. I quickly realized I couldn’t have my 3 monitors plugged in for this game. If I did when the game launched I couldn’t click on any of the menu buttons and several keys didn’t work properly for the key mappings. For example “W” to move forward would spin me around. After unplugging my 3rd monitor and having just my main monitor and secondary plugged in the problem stopped. The game is locked to 60 FPS. There is an option for Vsync but it still only went to 60 FPS and I couldn’t get it to go to 144 hz like my monitor supports. The game is fluid though as it’s not a fast paced game. It ran at a constant 60 FPS for me aside from a couple moments in the caves where during a cave in it dropped to 48 FPS for a few seconds. Alt-Tab doesn’t work. There are no manual save options but with the short length of the missions and game it’s not really an issue. There are two settings for AA and two other graphics settings to adjust. The game uses the Unreal Engine 4.10 and takes up 6.31GB of disk space.

	I think if the story was fleshed out more I would be able to give the game a higher score and recommend it. As it is the crashes, abrupt ending and general lack of polish keep me from doing so. The gameplay is decent, the story is interesting so there are good points to it’s favor and there are enjoyable parts to it. I paid $5.49 CAD for Cat Interstellar and I feel it’s a fair price for it. Had I not had the issues with it that I did than I would have said the $10 range would have been alright as well. This is not a bad game but one that couldn’t realize it’s potential.

My Score: 6.5/10

My System:

49520826.review:
While it is far from a perfect game, it is, in my opinion, hard to deny the beauty and amazing concept this game provides. In many ways it seems to be the exact definition of an indie game. Made by likely as few as one person; "CAT Interstellar" exceeds at showing the player that often times, less is more. Taking myself roughly only 2 hours to complete (could have been way shorter but I explored everything), it left me satisfied, and with more questions than when I started. Mostly questions of, "Will the developer have a follow-up? What if this were a larger scale game made by a big name studio? How would we, as a species, approach a feat as large as colonizing Mars?" Nothing which takes away from what this game is. 

As stated above, a very small production team of possibly as few as one person designing the game, accomplished quite an impressive feat. Graphics and textures were smooth and believable. Sound design was simple: It's hard to know what Mars sound like, but having some atmosphere it's not impossible to make a guess that it has plenty of wind and sand drifting across plains of open land. Despite there being few voice actors for the NPCs, the VO was actually rather good. I have no complaints. Aside from the graphics, what really impressed me was the music of the game. It was mysterious, yet fulfilling and completely fit the letter for setting the mood for the landscape of Mars. 

All in all, I absolutely recommend playing this game.

48706052.review:
[h1]In short: Skip it, you aren't going to miss out on anything.[/h1]

I like Indie and experimental games that try doing something different from the mainstream genres and I do support the efforts of the devs here (that's why I bought it). But CAT Interstellar leaves a lot to be desired.

The only Pro of this game is that the graphics are decent, but after that it is pretty much downhill (literally).

They warn you about the shortness of the story but they don't tell you that you can do EVERYTHING possible in this game in under an hour. I haven't gotten all the achievements but I know exactly what they are and where they are. The only reason why I didn't bother getting them was because I just wanted to figure out why the game is named CAT. You will notice that I have nearly 1 hour of game time and that's primarily because I got lost at a certain area in the game and kinda kept going in circles for about 15 minutes. 

The payoff was the only thing that I hoped would get me to recommend the game but ... well, it's disappointing. The last chapter of the game is the most frustrating of the lot. The movement gets slowed down EVEN MORE and the actual reveal is probably about 10 seconds (could be less, don't quote me on that). It doesn't give you any closure, nor does it even try to explain much and the whole story just collapses on itself.

FUN FACT: When I said that you can do EVERYTHING in an hour, that includes even the CREDITS!

48082979.review:
This is one of the biggest whiplash "WTF" experiences I have had with a game. About 50 minutes of decent but exceedingly slow paced casual 'what if mars' scifi walking-sim game (with some very light platforming and a few fetch-quests), focused on worldbuilding and slowly revealing the setup to a first-contact story. Then all that VERY suddenly ends (in a way that isn't even totally clear if its scripted or not, at first), and sends you into an epilogue which is like a glimpse into some whole other story, with absolutely nothing explained. Then the credits sequence is an epilogue to the epilogue, back in the original story, which throws more weird unexplained plot at you in the final seconds. Overall it feels like an early proof of concept adaptation of some novel or short story that the creators just assumed anyone playing it would already know.

I would have sworn that when I got this (some months ago) it was a free VR game? But now it's flat only(?) and apparently costs $5, and I honestly can't say if that moment of pure surreality in the transition to the epilogue is worth any amount of money or not. Nothing else in it really is.

48012913.review:
Kinda not a game, more of a walking sim with some interactive bits.
So it should be viewed as a piece of art. Not very good art.
It hints, ever so vaguely, at some cute sci-fi ideas, but absolutely nothing new or groundbreaking.
That said, it's not terribly bad or anything. There's a laugh or two in here. And it doesn't overstay its welcome. So overall it's a pleasant experience as it unfolds. But suffers from a dire lack substance and doesn't tie any of it all together by the end really.

So on the merits of a game, this earns a 4/10 to be generous - nothing is broken, but none of it is good really, and there's very, very little of it.
If you want a cute little 1h long demo with a home-cooked feel, get it for a couple bills. But don't expect it to be fulfilling in any true way.
I really want to recommend this, because you can feel there's some heart here and there's potential.
But, as an overall experience, it lacks any depth and fails to pull together anything coherent. So after all is said and done, it leaves you with a sense of disappointment.

Is this a good game?  NO - or rather, debatable...

Is it a good story?  YES, albeit very short, but it's interesting.

Is it worth the $5 asking price?  HELL NO!  I got it on Humble for 50 cents and I feel for that price, it's TOTALLY worth it.  Asking $5 is an absolute joke.

So it's not actually a game, more of a short (hour-long, as stated in the description on the store page), walk-through story.  That being said, it REALLY shows what an indie team with very limited funds can create, given enough passion.  I would say that some AAA studios can take a few tips from 'games' like this.  The graphics and "gameplay" elements are AMAZING, the story is quite interesting, and I would absolutely buy a full priced game if this dev were to make an actual game.  The voice "acting" is bland at best, but that almost makes sense as every character is a robot - maybe it's that way on purpose?

I recommend this at the price I paid for it (50 cents) - nothing more.  Good job, devs!  I would be quite interested in future projects!

One of my pet peeves is people writing androids/robots too closely modelled on human responses, which is present in (relative) spades in this game, but it wasn't a dealbreaker for me.

43741092.review:
Frankly, I have strange feelings about this game. Seems like a nice indie that went all the pass from greenlight, through early access and up to complete release but at the same time seems like some crap. The developer warns that game is short, so I thought that it would be something like walking simulator with cats and space setting, but I got something strange…

No need to discuss every element in details, so in short: graphics – usual Unreal Engine 4, though if you leave the story path and decide to explore locations, you are likely to meet textures from the year of 2005. Gameplay – in this case it consists not of walking but rather hovering above the ground, though it changes nothing. Atmosphere – meh, so-so, you don’t feel like you are in space or on Mars. Music – also strange, youtube has an OST video, though I had only one composition playing during the whole game which is not even in this soundtrack. 

As for the plot… Well, things are not simple at all… It seems like the developers had a complete 3-hour story and they could fit only one hour of it into the game, so they, without much thinking, just squeezed the first of hour of it and released this as a complete game. The result is that the game ends when the actual interesting events start to take place. And if this was only the first episode I would compliment the game and start to wait for the continuation, but no! It is presented as a finished product, which it doesn’t seem at all. Plus, there is a nice twist at the end of the game, but in fact you are distracted from the main story and made to observe this twist, so the impression from it becomes something like: “Oh, okay…”  

And it seems like I should give a negative rate to this game, and that’s actually right. But, however, the game has its pros too, the major one I consider the voiceover. Yeah, indie game, made in garage with the budget of two sandwiches has great voiceover and sound effects. I don’t know what’s the soundtrack lying on youtube but both it and the melody I had during the game are nice. The global story is also interesting but too little time is dedicated.   

So, in the end we get a weak and unfinished game with decent potential. If the developers somehow will make a continuation they may create really interesting and decent game. As for now, it feels like a ripped out chunk of some story or its first episode, but not like a finished game at all.   

P.S. I can’t get why the game is entitled CAT Interstellar, cause whole game we are playing as a robot named DOG and we are gonna play as kitty only at the end of the game. So, from this point of view, even the declared feline in the tittle is in very small amounts here, so buying game only to see these cute furry creatures in space also has no point.

Spoilers abound, since I expect that the person most likely to read this is the game's author(s).

Cute, atmospheric, occasionally funny. Doesn't really quite hold together as a narrative experience at any point, but least of all at the end: You've got a perfectly good tragic ending, one that's caused by a threat that's been established well, that happens to characters you've grown attached to, and that leaves you wanting to know what will happen afterward... and then, instead of rolling the credits, you switch to a completely different and irrelevant perspective just to Planet of the Apes us?

42212956.review:
[i]CAT Interstellar[/i] is a classic example of a walking simulator, even though the dronelike robot you control is floating instead of walking. 

It's a very short game: it won't take you more than an hour to complete.

Graphics are very nice for an indie game but, unfortunately, the 'red planet' doesn't look red at all due to terraforming, so you won't really get the full 'Mars experience' you might expect.

[i]CAT Interstellar[/i]'s voice acting is impressive for an indie game. 

The story, however, is incomplete and confusing.

Man has sent a bunch of robots to Mars to terraform the planet into a livable habitat for humans. You play as a maintenance bot designated 'DOG' and you're sent out of the base to help some droids with their terraforming tasks.

The very, very brief story that unfolds is pretty much given away in the game's description on the Steam Store page, so if you haven't read that yet, I suggest you don't because you may want to find out what little story there is for yourself. 

After the 'big revelation', the story ends abruptly. After that, as an epilogue, you're a cat all of a sudden and you find out you're on Earth. This is revealed by directly ripping off the ending of a classic SF film. 

So the story about Mars ends all of a sudden without any decent conclusion, and you get a seemingly unrelated ending in the form of a 'cat simulator'. The developer had to explain the story he had in mind and had to admit it isn't presented very well in the game as it is. You may want to refer to the forums after having played through the game, like I did, and read about the story about Earth you were supposed to gather from the game: https://steamcommunity.com/app/384740/discussions/0/1318836262667162080/

To wrap up the story about Mars, the developer is apparently working on a sequel. Fine, but then I feel I have to say the price tag of €5 is excessive for a very short walking simulator that has an incomplete story to boot. 

In conclusion: sure, I recommend playing [i]CAT Interstellar[/i] if you can enjoy a short adventure game / walking simulator that certainly has some merit, but you should get it only when it's heavily discounted to 50 cents or the likes, as it certainly isn't worth a fiver at all.

42200707.review: Interesting little game. Not much story, about 1 hour of gameplay, 2 if you REALLY stetch it. Grab it if it is on sale and you like space exploration games.

42199229.review:
[url=https://kinglink-reviews.com/2018/05/23/cat-interstellar-review/] Full Review [/url] --  [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31803828-Kinglink-Reviews/] Curator Site [/url]

Cat Interstellar is a rather interesting game. It’s also a very short game, however, even a short game deserves consideration. The game came to my attention when I saw it was inspired by Robert A. Heinlein’s work “The Moon is a Harsh Mistress”. So I was interested enough that I bought it and played it.

So let me explain the “title screen picture”, there’s not really a title screen. You load into the game and instantly you’re walking around a space station. Now you can look down and see your android body, and you can talk to a few people and then you’re told to report to the Departures. At this point, I went to the main menu and found myself at the same level. So you work your way there, hearing a few people talk as you walk to the Departures section, and you suddenly see there are 5 levels and the credits. It appears all are unlocked from the beginning. Suddenly I got it. The level was the main menu. Odd. Very odd. So I used a picture from the credits.

This is also how you toggle subtitles, but subtitles don’t work on the main menu. Ok, that’s fine. In fact, I really have to say I like the subtitles in the game, but I just wish I had the option to turn them on everywhere.

That’s when the game gets even odder. You see you’re not an android, and in fact, you never use the android body on the main menu. In the game, you are “Dog IV”, a “Quadruped” floating android. At least you have four hover units, and you seem to be remote controlled, I’m not sure exactly what to call you.

You make your way around the port and end up having to explore it finding the way out, but first having to go to the lab to talk to someone (which means stand there and hear a few lines of dialog).

The fact is this is really the game. Most of the game gives you a level to explore and usually a mission, which as you try to perform has a side mission. In the first level, it’s to go to the mines and you are asked to go to the lab first.

There are a few interesting features of the game, a small number of destructible environments, a couple of interesting quests, and a few places to go, but the problem of the game is that section that I just described, about going to the lab, takes about 20 minutes, and it’s a fifth of the game.

Yeah, Cat Interstellar is an hour long, and if that’s not for you, I understand, I’ve reviews of a lot of other games that take longer and might be up your alley. However, I played the entire game so I think I should delve deeper into it, in case anyone is still interested in playing it.

So the game claims it’s based on The Moon is a Harsh Mistress by Robert A. Heinlein, and I was expecting something grand. Even at an hour long, there’s a lot of short stories Heinlein wrote that could be read in an hour, so I wanted something that I could sink my teeth into and think about. Ultimately I didn’t get that. Heinlein’s writing is special, and I’d say I’m a huge Heinlein fan, I’ve read most of his books and absolutely adore his writing. Stranger in a Strange Land is probably my most favorite book ever.

So while The Moon is a Harsh Mistress might be a basis of the game, the game ignores much of the writing. It ignores the political plot, the workers unionizing, libertarian overtones, the fighting with Earth. Really the only thing this game takes from it is the location and some technology.

Now I understand the difference in media. No one wants to play The Fountainhead or Atlas Shrugged. In fact, I’m sure most people wouldn’t want to read it. No one is looking forward to being locked in a room in a game and listening to a 2-hour speech. That would really kill the experience fast. However, I understand taking the themes from Ayn Rand’s work and making Bioshock. Andrew Ryan is clearly John Galt, as well as others, the other characters are characters who easily could exist in Rand’s work and are based on a number of characters.

So a book to game adaption can work, as also seen by Enslaved: Odyssey to the West. The problem here is Cat Interstellar never tries to use the book. You have androids, you have the player as “Dog” and you have simple tasks. The game never gets deep enough to inspire anything beyond a simple game.

That’s the real shame here. The game engine is fine, the game levels are fine, the side quests are annoying but it adds length. What really hurts this game is that the length is only about an hour long, and the game never attempts to have a story, just actions it wants the player to do. Even when the game finally does have something interesting, you get an android saying “This is odd.” and then five minutes later the games practically over. There’s no depth to this story, and it feels unfinished.

If you want to read more and see a final score, you can see the full review with pictures and video at https://kinglink-reviews.com/2018/05/23/cat-interstellar-review/  You can also check out my Curator page at If you want to hear more from me, you can show me that by following my curator at http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31803828-Kinglink-Reviews/

41518189.review:
[b]CAT Interstellar[/b] is a short sci-fi adventure which falls short on the most basic principle of a good story, having an ending. Any ending good or bad, even a cliffhanger, would have been acceptable. Unfortunately CAT Interstelar, which currently provides about an hour's worth of content, ended up so abruptly that left a sour taste and the thought of having wasted my time in mind!

Such a huge disappointment and wasted potential to a great could have been adventure, even to par with the likes of The Solus Project. It should have been labeled as a technology DEMO with no replayability and priced accordingly. I can only assume the developer either was lazy to provide an ending or ran out of funds and just abandoned the project in a hurry.

Still, as a tech demonstrator, CAT Interstellar shows enormous potential. Very good graphics and rich environments, which are hardly taxing even on a modest system (tested on an old GTX860M laptop). And even with its minimal interactions, the caves part of the story felt like I was back into "Gliese-6143-C" for the briefest of moments and then... the end.

Last but not least, the excitement of exploring the project's assetts that were supposed to be free (as a DLC), was dampened as the download option just starts the main executable. As such I cannot really recommend CAT Interstellar unless it is on sale and heavily discounted.

-----
+ Good graphics for 3-4 detailed environment locations
+ Interesting voice over one-liners for the bots
+ Provides 1hr's good entertainment and intrigue
+ Showcases IonizedGames's capabilities and high production values
+ Achievements and trade cards

- Way too expensive for what feels like a tech demonstrator
- Minimal interaction with the environments and underdeveloped actors
- Basic sounds and lack of background noise for an inhospitable place like Mars
- Annoying time wasting starting from "departures" location each time while achievement hunting
- Project assetts DLC not working
- VR implementation would have made it worth its price tag

This is barely a thumbs up, but I think the developer tried to do something interesting and should be praised for that. The environments are well crafted and different for each level. It is mostly a walking simulator. You are rewarded for exploring by overhearing snippets of dialog that fill in the story. The voice acting is excellent.

The devs make no secret about the fact that it is a short game. I took a little longer than average but I explored amost everything there was to explore.

There are some flaws. Sudenly there is some platorming on level 3, and no really obvious way to do it. I died twice, resulting in a respawns that basically solved the puzzle for me. On level 4 the game wouldn't let me go past a barrier. I spent about 10 minutes looking around for another way out before giving up and restarting the level (a process that isn't super easy since there is no main menu). When I went back through I figured out what went wrong, but the game needed a bit more play testing at that point and a way to prompt the player. I'm sure I'm not the only one to get stuck at that point.

And then there is the final level, which is a bit weird. The devs probably didn't know how to end the story but as one other reviewer said, it probably should have just ended after level 4. This is one case were an editor would have just scrapped the final chapter and let it end where it really ended.

But the ending credits are pretty cool.

It's a weird one.

I like short science-fictiony story games like this. It's pretty enough, and a cool setting with some neat ideas.

The story is the trouble though. Just when it was starting to get interesting, when the twist is revealed... there's a short chapter where you're a cat instead (which does connect to the story in an amusing way admittedly) and then the credits. Nothing is resolved, or explained, it's just suddenly over when you think you're only half-way through the narrative.

I can only assume it came down to budget issues and a need to release the game before it was ready. That's a real shame. 39139596.review:
The main character, Dog, controls beautifully for a walking simulator, moving comparatively swiftly. The level on the planet surface is where the game truly shines for me; rather than move painfully slowly like in most walking sims, you can speed along the dunes like a dog unleashed, and the game strikes just the perfect balance between serenity and wonder for me, which considering what you're actually doing is a small miracle. Well done!
　
It must have been there that I completely blew the alleged allotment of 1 hour: I ended up with 3.5h total, for story, all achievements, the easter egg location on the surface, being rather sick -- not game-induced, I believe -- and telling spouse in detail about it, as you do, so let's dock 40 minutes for that last bit. There are some minor points against the game (all characters but the main one move like molasses; subtitles setting does not stick between sessions; NPCs seem to talk to your character when they reach a certain location, regardless of whether you're actually near enough to hear them when it happens -- you can ask them to repeat themselves, but only for the very last bit of dialogue), but the single big one is this: there's a fair bit of hints and exposition, but the pieces never quite come together as a proper narrative. While I'm not sore on general principle that the game is short (like many of y'all, I have a backlog of several hundred games; I *like* short games, and the attainable goals they offer), I think giving the game one or two more hours of breathing space, and better telling therein, would have made this a clearer winner. Well that, or the main exposition droid said something of complete genius to me while I was at the other end of a cave. Either/or.
　
As it stands, $2.99 / £2.49 are easily justified (possibly .50 more) if you like walking sims; but I may have preferred to pay twice that for a good, tight narrative and, if needed for that, an hour or two of extra runtime.

[h1]CAT Interstellar is an entertaining and smooth interactive walking simulator that left me wanting more.[/h1]

The game starts with you controling an android, so I was surprised to learn that the majority of the game you are controling a dog like robot. The environments were well done and kept my interest. I also appreciated how you could interact with any of the androids you came across. Their dialogue made the world feel interactive and alive. The length was unfortunate, but to be expected for the price. I think the ending segment could have been handled less abruptly though. It was as if you were playing the prologue to an exciting sci-fi adventure. I don't mind the sudden conclusion, but I wanted at least some sense of an explanation for the statues. Missing that feels unsatisfying.

Regardless, I am eager to hear about the future of this developer. CAT Interstellar runs amazing and looks excellent for such an inexpensive title. Pick it up if you can.

There are no jump scares.

35782695.review:
CAT Interstellar is a great little tech demo.  It feels like the beginning of a much larger game.    Some parts of it are highly polished, and it plays through perfectly.  

You take the role of some kind of automated roaming robot, sent to go help out a colony on mars after some 'quakes have caused some disruptions...   

Starting out in orbit, the sense of scale and the wonderful modelling of robots and ships is great.   The first section is a "getting to know the controls" kind of area, but showcases the capabilities of the demo very well.  The game has a few more 'inside' sections which look like a generic futuristic 'factory' or whatnot, and then you're out on the Martian surface.

The surface is great, although I would have expected Mars to have more little boulders everywhere... It feels more like a section of map from "Borderlands", perhaps... all deserty and rock-outcroppy.     The map is populated with a few buildings, and some robots which are just going about their business.  They all talk to you, have different things for you to do, or just pass the time of day with you.. It's quite nice, relaxing in a way.

Once you get into the third section, you start to get a feel for what the "story" would be if the game was expanded into a full story arc... There are unexplained things, and wondrous things.. All of it is lovingly rendered, and the interior modelling is some of the best I've seen outside of a AAA game.

Everything about CAT Interstellar is great.  This is very definitely a labour of love, and although it's not a proper game per se, it's definitely interesting to play, and it has a very weird ending which (to me) says "Look, floating robots is one thing, but we can also do *this*"... and it's great!

I hope this gets made into a game at some point, it's intriguing!

35532278.review:
READ THE DESCRIPTION. It says "This game is a short story ~1 hour long that is meant to be played in a single sitting."

That's about right. What it doesn't say is that the story doesn't have a real conclusion; just as you discover something interesting, there's a scene change to something else entirely, and you do that scene wondering when you get back to the real story, and poof! roll credits. Nothing is explained or developed. It's like the BEGINNING of a good story ... one the storyteller hasn't bothered to tell.

Beautiful game, good physics, voice work is fine, Dog is fun to control, all the elements of a good game or even a good walkthrough story are ready to go ... it's just missing the story.

I'm giving this game a thumbs-up because I don't feel my hour or my three dollars were wasted. If I'd spent more than three dollars or more than an hour on it, though, I'd feel like I hadn't gotten my time or my money's worth.

35119935.review:
[h1] For once a short story that isn't completely dull [/h1]
 
 
Truthfully I did enjoy CAT Interstellar, it is a good example of “quality over quantity” but the game really wasn't enough for me.
 
Although the question is, will you enjoy CAT Interstellar? Let discuss some of the features the game offers.
 
 
[list]
[*][b][u]Graphics[/u]-[/b] So CAT Interstellar was developed with Unreal Engine, so the graphics have a mostly realistic look to them. Pretty much exactly what you would expect from a modern Unreal Engine game. Ionized Games took a interesting approach when they created Mars, it isn't red, which really caught me off guard. Don't worry there is a very good explanation on why Mars is looking so pale. 
 
[*][b][u]Gameplay[/u]-[/b] As much as they tried to avoid the “Walking Simulator” tag, that is pretty much what it is just with a little bit more interaction. That is by no means a bad thing in my mind. For most the game you get to hover around all kinds of locations as “DOG-VI” which is a little hovering robot which was molded amazingly I love they way it works and how all of its parts react to the environment. There is a few parts in the game that include player created destruction on some rocks which I found extremely under utilized.

[*][b][u]AI[/u]-[/b] AI is pretty much non-existent other than a few androids that run around and another one that follows you thought a section of the game. In a few occasions the following AI gets WAY to close and will often times trap you in a corner, leaving you no choice but to restart that chapter of the game. Which is fairly frustrating considering the game is pretty slow paced. 

[*][b][u]Story[/u]-[/b] The story of CAT Interstellar is the biggest marketing point for the game. So how good is it really? With how short the story is I really don't want to talk much about the specifics. Although for the most part I found it enjoyable and quite believable. That being said in my opinion the ending is a bit of a cop-out and seemed way to sudden, I do believe that the ladder was intended. Everyone that you come in contact with is a android, in my opinion the voice acting on the androids was good, but not right. The android seemed “too human” this is purely a matter of perspective but in my mind the androids had too much emotion in their voice and even used swear words a few times. 

[*][b][u]Replayability[/u]-[/b] I played through game twice while getting all the achievements, and that's about all I'll I will do. According to the developer the story is complete so I really don't see a reason to go back through again. Games that are this short really tend to lack replayability especially within a short time frame.

 
[*][b][u]Value for Dollar[/u]-[/b] With these short story games I have always had a hard time determining if they have good value for dollar. My philosophy for that is if a game is (for example) $15.00 I would want to get at least 15 hours of quality gameplay out of it. That philosophy just doesn't work with this type of game. I know the developer needs to get compensated for the work he has done but I do think the full release price of $4.99 is just a little bit too much. 

[*][b][u]What Would I do Different or add?[/u]-[/b] There really is only two things that I can think of that I would have really changed about the game: I would have liked to see more use of the destruction and I would have changed up the ending to seem less abrupt. 


If you have any questions or comments concerning the game or my review do not hesitate to ask!


[b][u]Reviewers Comments[/u]-[/b] Yes, I did receive this game at no cost to me, but I assure you that this review reflects my sole opinions of the game. The game was bought, not the review.

I bought CAT Interstellar in the hope that my 4.5 year old grand son would enjoy the story, like the graphics, and be able to handle the controls.  He likes Machinarium and we play through that game over and over.
   By playing other games, he has developed the ability to accurately use  WASD and the  mouse  to  control DOG. 
   He likes the graphics and his questions and my answers have made the story clear in his mind. He likes to solve problems
and isn't easily discouraged.
   We have played through the Mines Chapter and look forward to finishing the game. I've told him that I think there is a cat at the end of the story so he is eager to get there. 
   He likes to start every session  at Chapter 1. Repeating success is important for kids his age so he is not bored by replaying chapters as he often finds something new he missed in earlier play.
   This game, like Machinarium, will be a favorite of his and I am sure he will play it through over and over.

   I heartily recommend this game especially to grandparents (or parents that have the time and the patience) that are
looking for a violence-free game wih a story to play with kids or  grandkids.

                                                          **************   5 Stars out of 5 Stars  *********************

[h1]CAT Interstellar is off to a good start[/h1]

The game is EA, so be patient and understand that it's just a Very Short taste of what [b]may[/b] someday come. (y'know - The little sapling that is growing toward becoming the mighty oak). If you're a gamer who instantly expects hours of gameplay on a fully developed & polished game - Well, come back later, I guess, or stop browsing EA games altogether! xD They aren't for everybody.
Pros
1- Impressive Dev who comes across as humble, objective, respectful, and responsive to suggested improvements. Also very active/visible in discussions & Review comments
2- Nice graphics & smooth controls for kb/mouse (Sorry, I didn't try with my controller)
3- Voice acting & storyline are very good, and sound effects were well done (i.e. cave echoes)
4- Very fair price that matches the early state of development

Cons - none IMHO - CAT Interstellar is brief & does just what it says it does at this early stage

[strike]Other - My only silly pet peeve (pun intended) was the movement of the cat in the final chapter. Cats don't start moving slowly and gradually build up speed like a city bus - No, they take off like a bullet leaving the barrel of a gun. And when running with the cat & using 'jump' - Well, the jump is basically Straight Up instead of up and continuing forward at the speed of the run, and after it lands, y'know it starts off again like that bus lol. (everybody's a critic, right).[/strike] My 2¢ - Cheers

**EDIT 15AUG2017 - Gave 2nd playthrough after updates & enjoyed it. The cat motion referenced above is much quicker and natural now. Foggy Nelson has a resting spot. Interactions & movement felt better overall. A tiny bit more content has been added and it all wraps up nicely. Kudos to Devs for a nice, short, and enjoyable story.

32794200.review:
A good buy at $4, and I was surprised to see it on on the Summer Sale... for a mere $0.99, it's worth getting to see if you are at all curious. 

I'll try to avoid spoilers. As the description says, this game takes place on Mars and involves work to get it terraformed. Terraforming isn't the same as colonization, and if you aren't sure of the difference, what it means is that the planet has to be made habitable before people can survive there. Terraforming is what's happening here. 

PROS: Your character is easy to move around. From reading around the game's Steam page, the character went through some work to get it to where it behaved as fluidly as it does now and isn't buggy as it used to be. You will find using your character to be very intuititve. The HUD: Blessedly there's no HUD. Hooray! More time to study the environment and get engaged with the story, less time reading a list of action items and setting up hot bars and checking mini-maps. Your NPCs provide incremental storyline and tell you what's up and what you're expected to do, and the environment provides visual cues to get you there. Audio: The NPCs beep a lot and it was annoying to me. Thankfully the dev has a slider that lets you quieten them down without quietening the rest of the game. Minor quibble, I wish there was a way to run-back to see what they said last because sometimes I missed because I was too busy running around, exploring. Exploring: Wow! The surface is beautiful and curious, but the underneath is pure imagination-fuel. Lastly, something surprised me and has left me veeeerrrrrry curious of what the full story will reveal when the full game comes out this Fall. 

CONS: So far I have no cons. Just typical EA stuff. It's short, has a few annoying bugs, can be a bit clunky, and unfortunately the visuals options are few. However the game dev seems diligent and responsive to the community. And they made a post recently that explained the reasons for the changes to the sliders on the graphics. Game still looks great, though. None of this is a deal-breaker to me.

For such a small work, the game is a clever concept that has some really complex storytelling elements at work. 

Snagged during the Summer Sale 2017 for $0.99 USD. As short as it is, there is a lot here already and a lot of potential, so I'm looking forward to the full release this fall.

32146494.review:
I bought this on a whim, because it looked cool. I had seen that it got mixed reviews, but it was on sale, and I guess I was sold by the video. I also knew that it was a short story, but I didn't realize how short, or that it's unfinished. It probably should be labeled as an early release. If I had known how short it is, and that it's unfinished, I'm not sure I would have bought it. I like supporting early releases when it looks like a cool game, but the story is so short that I'm likely not going to play it again for months, when I finally notice it's been updated.
That extreme shortness, and the abrupt switch to a cat suddenly at the end makes me want to give it a negative review, BUT it really is cool. Is it worth a few bucks? Probably. Barely. But if you go in expecting a full game, even a short one, you'll probably be disapointed.
The menu system is the first thing you'll see. They try to use this projected 3D menu that acts like an object. It's really gimmicky and hard to use. You play as a little floating robot, nicknamed Dog, or DAWG, or something like that. There are a few small glitches with objects that happen occasionally, like seeing through them by accident, but overall, it's pretty well done. The physics of objects you move isn't really though. They fall like styrofoam.
You basically have to pilot this little robot around this building to find your way to the mines. I found this way harder than I should have. I kept going in circles, and not being sure which way to go. There are two missions before the mines of just moving things, and another one that was getting around scary heights to access some panels. Once you're in the mines, you're basically just trying to navigate a maze, with no idea what rocks you're supposed to pulverize. Overall, the game is really nice looking, but way too short, and really should be flushed out more. The robots don't look great, and there are some lighting issues, but the caves and the rolling hills look awesome. The lighting issues make parts of the game really hard. I ended up eventually turning up the brightness, which kinda felt like cheating. The stupid humanoid robot that follows you at one point will totally block you into a corner as well, and you'll have to try to jump over him. My guess is that the final version won't be as short, but I have my doubts that it will feel complete to the massive setup they did.
They have this at such a low price point, I can't see them making it into more of a full game, but I think it's a waste to just throw away the world building they did. I think they should work on hashing it out to recover it's rating, and make it more fun, especially for repeatability, and then do either some DLC, or a sequal. As it is now, it's not even really fully playable once. Feels like playing an alpha, but with release level graphics.

31733448.review:
EDIT: Formatting issues

I purchased CAT Interstellar way back around when it was first released on Steam, and according to my time log I played for around 0.2 hours (which I have no memory of) and never touched it since. Today, though, after scrolling through my games and seeing CAT in my list for the millionth time, I decided to give it a go. 

The game lasted just under an hour, which included exploring most every nook and cranny before I proceed on the main path. The story itself is very short and light, but is interesting [b](*MAYBE SPOILERS* after this point)[/b] and left me wanting to know the fate of 42 and DOG. The short cat level at the end was a bit unusual, and the cat definitely needs some work (as the dev is aware of -- the shaders are a bit off on the fur, and the movement needs to be improved.) Though unusual, the closing cat level still left me wondering how things are going on earth, and how it ties into DOG and 42. [b](*END POSSIBLE SPOILERS*)[/b] As far as controls, optimization, or bugs/glitches go, I didnt really run into any problems other than the cat controls (which are being worked on.) The audio is decent, though some voiceovers could use a little work. The UE4 rendered graphics are solid, not good nor bad. They get the job done. 

Would I recommend it? Yes, if you got it for free or maybe on sale. Would I pay $4 for it? Probably not, but it's up to you if up to one hour of decent gameplay and a short but interesting story is worth your money. Gameplay realistically is around 20-30 mins for an A to B person or about 40-50 mins for someone who likes to explore.

31719059.review:
I got this game as a free key from Chrono.gg. The idea sounded fairly weird and unique so it only made sense to give it a try. If it managed to convince me, I was prepared to grab a few copies for a few friends to compensate for getting a free one myself. After reading the reviews and seeing people complain that the game is like 15 minutes long, I was a little apprehensive. I spent around an hour in this game. I'm actually at a loss for words but not in the good way.

Optimization for lower end computers is not stellar, let's say that. The uh... "story"? makes me question what the point is. Maybe the point is to question what the point of the whole thing is but if that translates in me being utterly uninvolved and bored out of my skull, then I'd rather do without. 

I walked around, saw some stuff here and there, none of it was actually visually or conceptually interesting. I fiddled with some... things in some mine. And then something collapsed and then I walked around and then I was out... It's honestly just a huge blur. It really pains me to say it because I'm sure the developer is passionate but this game is such an aggressive absolute void of charisma.

I'm the type of person who has memorized hundreds of pages of factoids about complex lores like Metal Gear and I can't even remember a single thing that happened in this game (nor why it happened) just moments after finishing it.

To the dev: Please make sure to actually DESIGN your game. I know programmers tend to think they can do everything themselves but for Pete's sake talk to a designer. Your game is extremely lacking in basic conveyance and it makes a really piss poor job at subtly funneling players on the right path. It's very easy to get to the "what the fuck do I do?" stage. And once you know what to do, it's even easier to ask yourself: "Why the fuck am I doing this?"

To any potential buyer: I'm sorry but just don't waste your time, at least not yet. In case anything changes by the time it leaves Early Access -- and I kinda expect it won't -- then I'll update this.

30934957.review:
> CAT Interstellar is a short story-driven science fiction game about humanity's attempt to terraform Mars.

Let's break down the description.

> CAT Interstellar is a short

Indeed. Maybe 15 minutes of play time. Spent more than that wandering around an empty world realizing that there's nothing to do except knock over a few boxes.

> story-driven science fiction

I'll give it that. There is a story that moves along nicely and it is science fiction.

> game 

THIS IS NOT A GAME! This is a walking simulator where a robot that wanders around looking at things for no particular reason while other robots tell you things.

> about humanity's attempt to terraform Mars.

Alledgedly, you are on Mars. The story really isn't about humans or their attempt at terraforming. The story is about following some pipes into a cave and walking through the singular path in said cave until you, an AI robot named "dog", [spoiler]find some alien stuff, magically appear back inside, and turn into a cat with absolutely no explanation[/spoiler]. This is as far as the game goes in early access as of this writing.

This is early access, so I understand that it's not finished. However, I don't really see this being worth more than $1, nor why this kind of game would be early access. It's like getting early access to a book that's partially written. There's zero replay value.

My experience with Early Access games is mixed. Some games turn out great, other merely okay and a lot of games just never seem to get out of EA or are dumped on Steam unfinished. It's hard to tell how CAT Interstellar will end up. It could turn out to be an interesting experience. But at the moment it's a tech demo and very little more.
In the version I've played there is hardly any story. The androids you meet have little to say and there is very little information to be gotten from the computer monitors as well. You interact with the world with some super advanced levitation ray instead of a more realistic robotic arm or claw. Two of the androids will send you on fetch quests while idling and doing absolutely nothing of interest. Why can't they solve their own problems, they have functional arms and legs, right? It get's a little more interesting once you get into the caves but then the story just ends. I spent most of my playing time mucking about, trying to see how far away from the base I could get (quite far actually). But there's barely fifteen minutes of actual playing time present. There are very few items that you can interact with. It get's worse if you consider that during the first few minutes (out of the fifteen) most controls are shut down because you'll be locked into a tutorial and can only move when they let you. I don't like when I'm treated like a disobedient three year old. Maybe things will pick up from chapter 2 onward, but there is no way of telling right now. 
In short: I advise you to wait for the full release and check the new reviews then. In it's current state there really is no reason to bother.

26025481.review:
Review of CAT Interstellar

Before starting, please note that this review contains spoilers. If you'd prefer to avoid spoilers, please do not continue reading.

This review is a re-evaluation of CAT Interstellar, six years after my initial review in 2016. The game developers requested that I replay the game to assess the updates and changes made since then.

Original Review (2016):
"I was uncertain about this game. Although it's an early access game, it seemed far from completion. The textures looked bad, and the text above the robots' heads was too small, poorly designed, and difficult to read. The robots' voices were also irritating. Overall, I couldn't recommend the game in its current state."

Revised Review (2023):

Storyline: 1 out of 5
The game's storyline is unclear, as it does a poor job of explaining its premise. It seems to be based on the book "The Moon is a Harsh Mistress" by Robert A. Heinlein, but since I haven't read the book, I cannot provide details on the plot. However, a brief synopsis of the book may provide an idea of the game's potential background.

Design: 4 out of 5
CAT Interstellar features 4K textures that enhance its appearance. However, it feels more like an asset flip game than one developed from scratch. Despite six years of development, not much has changed, which is disappointing.

Mechanics: 2 out of 5
I recommend using a controller for this game, as the mouse and keyboard controls are not enjoyable.

Music and Voice Acting: 4 out of 5
The voice acting is well-executed, but I can't recall any notable music as I usually play with the music off.

System: 2 out of 5
The game is plagued by numerous bugs and glitches, with players getting stuck in various locations. Gravity can be manipulated easily, causing the android to move with objects and sometimes crashing the game. The game crashed frequently in OpenGL (native Linux) but not when played in Wine. There is still much work to be done, and it seems the developer may lack the time or experience to address these issues.

Conclusion: 3 out of 5
CAT Interstellar looks good, but there's not much substance to the game. It feels like a 3D visual novel game with an asset flip, and the storytelling is subpar. The controls are minimal and better suited for a controller. It doesn't take long to complete the game, and despite being in development for six years, it's far from finished. My recommendation remains unchanged.

CAT Interstellar is a PC and Xbox space exploration and trading game developed by CatLab and released in January 2019. Players assume the role of a space trader and explorer, navigating a vast, procedurally generated universe populated by various alien species. Players can explore planets, establish settlements, and trade goods with others.

The game offers a range of missions, from straightforward trade runs to more complex objectives like rescuing survivors or investigating mysterious signals. A crafting system is also available for creating items and upgrades, along with a research system for discovering new technologies.

Visually, CAT Interstellar boasts impressive, detailed graphics, including planets, star systems, and nebulas. The game also offers an ambient soundtrack that accompanies different events. CAT Interstellar is optimized for lower-end PCs and doesn't require a high-end gaming rig to run.

TL;DR : No sense of purpose, bad narration, empty levels.

While not entirely catastrophic, I strongly discourage anyone from getting this game at this level of development.

I feel there are many problems with this game, the main one being the core gameplay: While I enjoy "walking" simulators, I find them attractive because they give me a strong sense of emotional implication through storytelling, this is absolutely not the case with CAT.

You control a sort of hoverbot in really boring straight, uninterresting corridors while androids are talking (mostly meaningless chat) to you like they had feelings... No emotional implication at all.
Compared to another similar indie game "Dear Esther" (OK the comparison is hard, this game is a masterpiece) you have a strong emotional implication: You feel human, you feel alone, the voice of the narrator is amazing, the sound design is beautiful, you wan't to find out what happened !

Another problem is the general graphical aspect of the game, the "levels" are small and yet really empty, badly designed and lacks some purpose which gives an sensation of wandering around aimlessly.

Finally: Why giving the player a torch if it's to light up the underground levels like it's midday ? Plus the lights are placed completely randomly above some kind of magical fluorescent mushrooms: You don't feel the light comes out of these mushrooms, you feel it comes from somewhere above them.

I was genuinely looking forward to playing this, but had kept putting it off for one reason or another. FInally, the stars alligned, and I sat down to try CAT Interstellar. I was greeted with a small screen depicting a level select, and chose the first one, eager to get my probin' on. 

There was a short loading screen, and suddenly there I was: A small interplanetary probe in all its glory. I appeared to be being worked on by two androids who told me that, due to the rough nature of the planet, the mines were collapsing, and I had to reach the surface. I found the elevator with no trouble, and "stepped" out onto the large Mars-like surface of the planet. Being a drone with hovering capabilities, I decided to head for the largest mountain I could find. 

My tiny motor made a lot of noise as I climbed, and as I reached the precipace, I was immediately swallowed by an unmeshed mountain texture and fell into the world below. I spent about three of my six minutes trying to escape from that glitch.

I think I'll wait a bit to play this again. I would've had to restart and go all the way through all the dialogue again, and at the moment, it just wasn't worth it to me.

Edit: Dev commented and I felt bad that I didn't praise the aspects of the game I loved in tandem with criticizing what I didnt, so here's that portion. 

The map itself looked fantastic, from what I had seen. The mining colony feels wonderfully claustrophobic and tight, with it's multiple grey hallways stretching on. Then you hit the surface, and I have to admit, there was a decent amount of awe in that first moment. The entire planet seems to stretch out before you, and part of the reason I got stuck was because I was so excited to take a look at the world in the first place. Also due to the quick reply from the dev, and my hopes assuaged that this issue will be fixed, I am changing my review from negative to positive, as I now have a lot more faith that most of the major issues will be ironed out in due time.

24584467.review:
After playing for a while, I have this strange feeling that you want feedback on the early access version of your game...

I'm playing V1.8 by the way.  

To start, I really like the way the controls work.  Right from the start, I can use either the WASD and/or the arrow keys to move around without having to edit keyboard options.  That's awesome!  The mouse also works corretly without having to search for the option to invert the Y axis and fumble with it, which is an annoyance that most other games make me do.  Two aweomes!!  And I like how the scroll wheel zooms in and out, and if I zoom in all the way it's like being in first person view.  Three awesomes!!!  You guys have done everything right as far as controls go.  

One thing I would love to see you add is support for a Logitech USB game pad.  After seeing that you got the keyboard and mouse controls right, I was disappointed that it didn't respond to my game pad, even when I tried to map thumbstick movements to in-game movement.  I assume you're planning to add that, right?  RIGHT?!?!  Remember: the de-facto standard most games have adopted is that the left stick controls translation (movement) while the right stick controls rotation (camera).  But you already know that, right?

I also like that it's a relatively open world.  I hate games that put me on a rail or in a tunnel, even if it doesn't look anything like a tunnel.  I was free to explore and find the guy who needed help loading some fertilizer into a thingy without being told to do so.  Brilliant!  

One thing that gave me a slight delay was when the game first starts and I'm inside a glass box overlooking Mars (am I riding a space elevator down to the surface?).  It didn't respond to my mouse movement until I clicked my mouse on nothing in particular.  That's no big deal, but you might want to fix that.

Another thing that impressed me at this opening screen was (1) my shadow was actually a shadow of me, not just a hazy gray blob, and (2) the shadow moved with me and mirrored my movements as I walked around inside that glass box, and (3) when I looked down, I had a body and feet!  Most games when I look down, I have no feet.  Little details like this really improve a game!  You guys are brilliant!

I'm guessing the story involves a deeper mystery than merely the mine causing some geologic instability, right?  But don't tell me now, I want to play the game when you finish it and experience the full story arc.  For example, why am I a robotic dog?  Why is the Mars base populated only by robots, especially when the base looks as if it was meant to be manned by people (windows, computer terminals with keyboards, etc.)?

One little thing that tends to bother me in a lot of games (especially sci-fi games) is the sameness of all the textures.  According to your latest release notes, you just combined a bunch of textures to reduce the game size from 8 gb to 4 gb.  But I think that may have gone too far with that.  I realize that you have to economize on graphics storage, but it loses something when, for example, all the doors are identical.  For example, IMO, not all doors should be pressure doors, only the doors between sections.  Most of the doors to individual rooms should be ordinary flimsy hinged doors--too many games put heavy duty pressure doors on EVERYTHING, even into a closet, lol.  Likewise, elevator doors should look like elevator doors, not airlock doors--study how an elevator actually works mechanically and you'll realize it's nigh impossible to make an elevator door a pressure door.  Just my opinion, of course. 

Oh, let me add that I was able to play an earlier version at a friend's house last week.  I think the start of that earlier version works better than the start of 1.8 because the robot who activates DOG gives you a better sense of your purpose in life as a robotic DOG that's just been delivered and activated that moment.  By actually talking to you and leading you through the base to the exit and giving you an assignment to go help out in the mine, that seems to make more logical sense to me than just turning the DOG on for the first time and then ignoring him to stumble around searching for where to go and what to do--even if the game doesn't actually force you to go anywhere in particular or do anything specific once you leave the base.  I realize, again, from your change log that you want to get away from robots talking to each other in voices--and that makes sense--but I think we players neeed at least a little handholding at the very, very start, even though that contradicts what I said earlier.  So I think you should put that setup back in.  But again, just my opinion.

24242807.review:
Alas, I'm going to have to give [i]CAT Interstellar[/i] a thumbs-down for the time being. I really wanted to like this; I certainly want to encourage the development of more science fiction themed VR experiences, and the visuals in this game (or, to be fair, small part of a game) look fab. The setting (Mars) and story (at least what is hinted at) are also both good.

So it's tremendously saddening that there is currently a persistent glitch with the rendering in this game -- afflicting many Rift and Vive users -- where your perspective as viewed through the HMD is permanently located about 2 metres away from where it should be: which is to say, floating above and off to one side of your in-game character. This means that whenever you turn your head to look around this beautiful virtual space the developer has created for you, the entire viewpoint slews around alarmingly because it is being rendered for an entirely different focal point than the one your eyes actually occupy.

To say that this leads to instant and quite severe motion sickness would be putting it very mildly indeed. This game is literally unplayable in its current state. Worse, after even a short exposure to this viewpoint-mismatch rendering, I became so green about the gills that I couldn't even go back into VR in normal, "comfortable" games that don't exhibit similar issues, because my vestibular system was still recovering from [i]CAT Interstellar[/i].

The author is aware of the problem and is working on a solution. I for one will be keeping my fingers crossed and shall check in on this game again in 6-12 months to give it another chance. But for now, I strongly recommend anyone who is at all susceptible to motion sickness to give this title a miss.

Dear Esther on Mars, but more interactive and with robots reminiscent of Portal.

Voice acting is pretty bad; note to the actors, memorize the lines and try to own them as your own words, rather than reading from a script.  The beginnings of the story that are present here are compelling enough though.
