21621705.review:
4th March 2016

Summary: This is a tech demo, not a game. Not worth buying. Future development may or may not change that.

tl;dr;

I bought the game about an hour ago, played for 27 minutes (played it twice). The first run took about 7 minutes, not 15. Possibly because I mistakenly thought I was doing the "intro" or "movement tutorial" and was expecting some gameplay when I suddenly found that I was not only at the end of the intro, but in fact the end of the game some 7 odd minutes later.

From the description I was expecting some gameplay. There isn't any. This is only a tech demo at this point in time.

You can move around (normal & fast) and you can jump. That's it. Yes, some physics, you can bump into boxes, drift higher over some terrain small obsticales an so on.

The game seems to be heading down a bit of a puzzle or "find/fetch & carry & dropoff & complete a mission" path given some of the voiceovers. It is not a direction I personally like, but ymmv.

Hopefully the dev focus switches to some actual gameplay pretty smartly.


Notes to Dev team:
The bounding box or cylinder on the 'dog' seems slightly too large.

Your game description talks of an intended / targeted release date of March 2016. A later post (update 1.6) says 1st June 2016. Update your game description to match your post.

Some of the ground clutter rocks seem a bit gravity defying.

Nice visuals, environment etc. Good tech demo.

20460980.review:
Review of the Alpha Release CAT Interstellar game

First of all, this is something of a "tech demo", and a very short one. You can be done under 30 minutes of gameplay. While the developer mention that this won't be a long game, it is to be noted the shortness of the game.

For an Early Access game, I gotta say it is very stable, functionnal and a visually appealing. The gameworld landscape seems big enough to wander around but without any objectives or thing to do, it ends up being pointless.

Another gripe was the lack of the current in-game objectives so I do believe that will be added later on.

This sums up to this:

PROS:
+Good visuals of the stations and planetary landscape.
+Sound design is ok.
+The open world seems big.
+Stable game with a functionnal menu.

CONS:
-Limited gameplay and quite boring for the moment. 
-Very short gameplay (finish the game under 30 minutes... supposed to be an hour long once fully released).
-Can't rebind the keys.
-No clear in-game objectives.
-The story seems interesting, more like a big teaser but there is no plotline at all!
-Ain't Mars supposed to have a reddish sky?

OVERALL:
Unfortunately, there is barely nothing to do in this "tech demo" game. Maybe it got released too early or something but I would have loved to have something worth of doing in the game! For a 8 GB download, I expected something with more meat but I just received a little bone thrown at me! Give me something to do like scan something or any kind of possible fun gameplay to be had. Any possible mysterious plotline could draw more gamers in!

I know the game is not pricy but that is not the point. There are games in this price range that offers more content for a longer playtime, but not this game. While Mars is an interesting planet, wouldn't the game setting been more appealing if set in another planet? Or maybe in an asteroid?

CONCLUSION:
For what it's worth, this game can have potential. Just not for now! Which is why I give it a thumb down and advice anyone to hold out until the game is completed.

20280094.review:
It's fantastical and cool. The mechanics of it are pretty solid. I like the visual design throughout the exteriors and especially interiors; I keep feeling parts of The Knights of the Old Republic. It does utterly lack a story. There's a bit of introduction to what DOG is, and then quite a lot of going places for very little reason. But it is not finished. The atmosphere of the game makes exploration interesting. The dialogue isn't well written and could benefit from better sound aquisition. The android designs are well done. A bizarre amount of screen tearing is omnipresent, which can wear a little thin. I think having a story down pat could really put this thing on rails and make for a great game. It's cheap enough and diverting enough and I'm interested enough to hang onto it for to see it finished. I recomened it for those reasons. 

To the crafstmen, 
 Work on your writing ya'll. It'll pay off in great-steaming-heaping massive dividends. If for no other reason, do it for Moe.

19946093.review:
Updating my review because I was going through my library and remembered I owned it.

I still do not recommend this game, especially at the new $10 price.

They have increased the playtime from 15 minutes to 45 minutes, possibly an hour if you explore more.

It's still a walking simulator, the extent of the actual added gameplay is basically "move this item a few feet over" and "break some rocks".

There is no map, no directional indicators, and no one tells you where the next path is. It isn't that big of a deal, as there's so little to explore that you'll find it in a couple minutes anyway, but it still would be nice.

A lot of the text boxes in the first area in the base have misspellings or grammar mistakes. Or they clip through walls, or get hidden behind grates.

There's also some random edgy libertarian takes for no reason just shoved in.

Once again, the basics of the game are great. The controls are smooth, the platforming is responsive, and the graphics look pretty nice. Unfortunately, nothing is done with them at all. The game flow goes:

Wander through the station until you find your boss

Go down an elevator

Go into the mine

Press some buttons (this requires the only platforming in the game)

fall into the bottom of the mine

Break some rocks to find your way out

cave in happens

You get a running sequence to escape

That's it. That's the whole game. It took them over five years to implement 4 buttons, 20 rock walls and a running sequence.

It's just not worth it. And as they've moved onto Episode 2,  it's unlikely that any of these will ever be fixed.

19031224.review:
As many have said, it's not much more than a tech demo at this stage of development, but a gorgeous and promising one. 

Things like gameplay, wonky controls or animation quality and even voice work can and probably will be improved, what I'm worried about more is the script. Exposition is as clunky as if the devs decided that they're going to draw from the worst aspects of that other Interstellar. 

But I sense potential problems with the premise itself. There isn't really any explanation as to why would fully mechanized staff communicate in natural language or why a rover performing menial tasks even need an intelligence this well developed to understand it. Did people, having developed a strong AI capable of jokes and self-consciousness, presumably decided that they're going to make everything intelligent above necessity just because they can? This seems like a huge overkill to me, I imagine even in THE FUTURE that kind of technology must be somewhat costly. 

If this game is suppose to be a fully developed story, it will need more character than this, because if all the heroes are some generic droids and rovers devoid of personality, like it is now, I can't see myself being too engaged by this narrative. Sure it might not depend on characters, but rather on ideas, but so far it doesn't seem seem to be heading into direction of a philosophical sci-fi and I don't honestly how it could with its current setup. 

Still, for 3€ it's worth checking out as perhaps we'll see something interesting come out of this. 

I wish the devs best of luck.

This game is gorgeous, though keep in mind this is extremely early access and the word "Game" at this point is being extremely generous. Right now, there's not much to it. It's basically a tech demo, but is fun to explore and look around.  For 3 bucks, you will prob get your money worth. Just don't go in expecting a game. The only game aspects is a couple instances where you are asked to go get this or that. 

As I said at the start, the graphics are gorgeous, and while I normally hate filters, the filters in the game make it look really nice. It does a nice job making you feel like a robot...or at the very least at the controls of a robot.

I wasn't a fan of the voice acting...Actually, that's a lie. The voice acting was tolerable, it was the scripting I had an issue with. hearing an android use words like "Awesome" just didn't feel right to me. Though the actors themselves could pass as androids.

My main concern is, like I said: The game is nowhere near completion, and in fact probably shouldn't even be released into early access yet. It has a long way to go before it's considered anything more than a demo. Anything can happen between now and then. 

However, I love what I see. If the game continues on the same track, this will most likely become one of my favorite games. 

Would I recommend it to you? If you understand the concept of Early Access, and you realize that the game as it stands right now is FAR from complete....then YES, I would recommend it to you. For 3 bucks? How could I not!?

17998895.review:
Straight off the bat, I have to say that I've *always* wanted to play a game where you're dumped on a planet and told "terraform this". I don't think there are enough games that really scratch that particular sci-fi itch, so CAT Interstellar earns itself a gold star right there.

Then I have to take away the gold star because both times I've tried to start the game up, I had to try maybe four times before it actually worked. I don't know if that's the game's fault, or my computer's, but I'm not having that problem with other games. Similarly I don't see any reviews here saying it's difficult to start up. So that's neither a positive or a negative comment, it's just something that happened to me.

My first and immediate thought is that I don't understand the title. The game is called CAT Interstellar, but you play a DOG module. That was a constant thought in my mind while playing the game. Is it a pun? What's happening? What does CAT Interstellar mean? "Construction And Terraforming?" That'd be pretty cool - CAT Interstellar is like, an offworld construction corporation, similar to Weyland Yutani or something. But then what does DOG mean?

Movement through the areas is entirely functional, if completely standard. WASD to move, mouse to look, shift to sprint, and space to jump. My only complaint is that that default non-thrustered move speed is so slow that you pretty much just have to keep one finger on the thrusters constantly. The double jump is a pretty nice feature though, makes bouncing through the admittedly gorgeous terrain very fun.

I love the androids too. The plasticy looking bodies with their glowing faces when they talk is really cool. They look like they've been committee designed to be "non-threatening", and "approachable". However I can definitely imagine them having some sort of hidden programming and when they want to be, totally terrifying.

Now, on to the niggles. This is stuff that I think could definitely be looked at and improved upon, but is by no way a deal-breaker from a gameplay perspective:

1) The DOG drone that you play. The texturing is... non-existant. As far as I can tell, it's just an ambient occlusion shader on the model, with some blue and some particles at the bottom of the thrusters. I don't know if this is because it's a placeholder for a final model/texture, or if it's by design, but I'm not too fond of it. And since we're going to be playing a game where this is constantly going to be on our screen, I kind of want a little more from it.

2) The sound mix of of the androids is very very quiet. I'm glad they've got subtitles at the moment, because while it's not too difficult to hear what they say, the quiet tones make it hard to really take it in. This sort of links in with my next point too.

3) Lots of telling, not much showing. So the DOG is equipped with a spectrometer that can detect stuff. But information about it is given to us via the quiet tones of the androids. I'd have liked it if one of the androids had gone "This is graphite, scan it, so your spectrometer can detect its chemical signature" Or *something*. Then it would have clued us in to what the blue splodges were on the ground that we're supposed to follow. You could have different samples of chemicals, and scan them all, so you can detect them while you're going around the planet, thereby finding more resources as you learn what the signatures of other deposits are.

4) The android by the skylift tells you to go find three boxes, and put them in the skylift. I did that. He then says "You lost all three?" No man, I put all three in the lift like you said. I don't know if I'm just not getting what he says, or if the wrong speech file is playing, but it doesn't make sense to me why he would say that.


Overall, this early access bit is really very short - almost too short to really get a good picture of what to expect from the full release. I really do hope that this turns into a fantastic game, because it certainly has the potential, and as such, I recommend it.

17764995.review:
Well, I hate to be the first one to say not recommended but will explain my reason and I will update it as the game gets updated. Price point is not a factor for my reviews so should mention that as well since many will look at the fact currently it is quite cheap.

[h1]TL;DR Version[/h1] 
If even a tad more of the story was included at launch or at least one interesting mission included at the beginning I may of swayed to the recommended side. Once more story is in then I may change my review to that.

[h1]Longer Version[/h1]

I do like the concept of the game and the terrain looks great but that is where it currently stops for me until more is added. I beat the game in 26 minutes and this includes doing the story, exploring, and throwing some random boxes around for fun.

You play as the "dog" which you can move, boost, jump, and grab objects although it looks rather plain in my opinion. You start off with being told a bit of the backstory of what is going on, I then was instructed to proceed outside to the next objective. At this objective I was instructed to find 3 boxes and move them to the skylift. After I completed that task I was told to go to the mine, an unforunate accident occurs there and that is the end of the game...currently.

This game will be story driven which is why at the moment I cannot recommend it, there just wasn't enough of the interesting bits added in for the launch which I wish I could of seen. Anything other than moving boxes could of been a better objective to start off with before further story is added on later that way I could of felt a bit more invested in the story before waiting for the rest to be put in. So basically to me, for a story driven game not enough of the story was available from the start.

The game itself runs quite well, no bugs or crashes from my playthrough at least. Option of VR or Play right off the bat in the menu which is great for those who want that.

I hope to see in the future a bit more added to the surface as it already looks quite good in my opinion but could do with a tad more added to it, and will await for the rest of the story. When a bit more of that is added in I will update my review to reflect that. I wish the developers the best of luck and hope to see the story evolve into something I will enjoy.
